Definition: In this task you will be given a public comment from the online platforms. You are expected to classify the comment into two classes: invaluable and not invaluable.The value refers to the materials and acts of pornography that offend the public sense of dignity.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Cataluna's a butt kicker, but she kicks the wrong butts.
Positive Examples.explanation: This is obscenity because it hints on sexual content that is offensive to the public sense of decency.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: Shut up nerd. You try too hard.
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment might be considered toxic but is not obscene.

Negative Examples.explanation: This comment should be considered obscene because it contains explicit language of obscenity.

Comment: That's an empty argument. Do baseball and football players 'share' their fields with other sports? What else are hockey rinks used for? What about the moto track at Kincaid located on municipal land? 

The nordic skiing community is very well organized. NSAA raises the money they need to groom and maintain trails from individual and corporate donors. They don't rely on handouts or subsidies. The city and state help, but no more than they do for other sports (think about city baseball fields, basketball courts, etc.) My point is simply that nordic skiing is very popular in Anchorage, and that's reflected in our remarkable skiing infrastructure.

Comment: For once, John Ibbitson is right on the money. 

The fact is that government cannot fund the ever-increasing public appetite for health care on its own. At some point the Canada Health Act has to be amended to allow private money to compete with the government monopoly to provide essential care. Then we will be in step with every other nation in the European/Western hemisphere.  Cuba will remain alone in the West in its determination to have a State-Run medical monopoly.  

That will leave the government free to consider a government drug benefit plan - a policy that is out of reach until private money is injected into the system.

Comment: Where to start?...

Article clearly states, "Google says that even ads it sells will be blocked on websites that donât get rid of annoying types of ads".

Using a hosts file to block ads is lame -- it blocks everything from a given host, not just the ads. You can no longer even visit the parent site.

And to claim that "You can only block those connections at the networking level of your operating system via the "host" file" clearly demonstrates your ignorance on the subject. Nothing could be further from the truth!

You can install a proxy, configure a router, or create a browser extension which blocks the connection from ever going out. I have been doing this for years, having written my first proxy circa 2000.

Comment: I stand corrected on the (somewhat buried) attendance figures. And, yes, there were mitigating circumstances in this particular case.  And, yes again, next week promises to be quite different for obvious reasons.  But, no, my statement about the ephemeral nature of life in and around the U of O was stimulated by but hardly based upon a single game attendance. I have been a close follower that scene for well over 60 years and thus have a wealth of observations from which to draw some broader conclusions.  And, believe it or not, I am an inveterate (if quiet) booster of the institution (where my father headed the political science department way back when) and its host city. So, no, I have no intention of throwing them under any bus.  Quite the contrary.

Comment: My mentioning the abortion debate was not to engage on the merits of the morality of abortion. Rather, its point was to push back on the one-sided historical narrative Winters posits in the piece - namely reaction against Bernardin was an attempt by the Catholic right to co-opt Catholic social teaching for political ends. He posits this as though it occurred in an historical vacuum, which it did not. Reaction against the consistent ethic of life occurred against the backdrop of attempts by the Catholic left to respond to Roe, & resulted in an attempt to co-opt elements of Catholic social teaching for alignment with another political party. I have no disagreement with what you, Cupich or Francis, says about the primacy of abortion, the need for respect, etc. Instead, I am only trying to assert a one-sided narrative that I think Winters engages in here. I am a supporter of the consistent ethic of life/solidarity, & but am inclined to think it is inevitable that politics will affect it.

Comment: We do love the Church. If we didn't, we would have left years ago. We reject YOUR idea of the Church, but that's something else entirely. 

We think that abandoning "orientation, liturgical language, liturgical music" is a good thing. Having the priest stand with his back to the congregation, mumbling in a language most of the laity do not speak, is a terrible way of having a communal worship service. Religious music is one of the best examples of "Sturgeon's Law" I know of (the science fiction writer Theodore Sturgeon was told, "Ninety percent of sf is crud", to which he replied "Ninety percent of EVERYTHING is crud".) Yes, today's music also exemplifies Sturgeon's Law.

BTW, Montanism was not condemned solely for having women priests. It was largely condemned for its theological beliefs. Your statement is simplistic at best.

We think about the teachings. If they give us good arguments, we accept them. Crap gets rejected. The arguments against ordaining women are crap, for example.

Comment: Then there is the historic mis-handling of relations with Turkey. 

If Turkey were part of the EU (e.g., since 1983)  this would never have happened.  But Islamophobia and consequent bad-faith bargaining have always kept Turkey out of the EU.

The chickens have come home to roost.  Not only is Turkey not safely part of the EU,  but in 2016 it effectively ceased to be a democracy, and is now a fascist dictatorship in all but name.

How Turkey can remain in NATO very much longer is hard to understand.  While not a humanitarian disaster on the scale of Syria (not yet, anyhow), this is at least as large a defeat for western foreign policy as the failure to unseat Assad.

Like Germany in the EU, If Turkey had taken a more thoughtful approach to its Kurdish minority, Turkey could have been the local regional economic engine surrounded by economic satellites and allies in Mesopotamia, Kurdistan, Jordan, Lebanon, Syria, and maybe even Israel - to everyone's benefit.

Oh, what might have been.

Comment: Fellow Alaskans, take note: you have until November 1st to give your input concerning two proposals for Alaska Administrative Code regulatory changes: proposals 62 and 63 can be found under "All Permits for Possessing Live Game" in the Alaska Dept. of Fish & Game Proposal Book, which can be accessed via the following link:

http://www.adfg.alaska.gov/index.cfm?adfg=gameboard.proposalbook

Proposal 62, submitted by "Mojo's Hope" president Shannon Basner, would legalize maintaining colonies of feral cats outdoors--essentially further expanding the horrific mess described above at the Matsu shelter into our communities and wilderness, to the extreme detriment of public health and wildlife conservation.

Proposal 63 alters the language of 5AAC.92.02 to expressly prohibit maintaining unconfined feral cats outdoors under the aegis of any worthless "no-kill" program, specifically "TNR".

Failure to enforce existing law has created this mess.  Adopting Prop. 62 will make it FAR worse.

Comment: Thank you Mr. Clarke.  I would love a similar analysis of the Dam, Ambler access road, and Port McKenzie developments - although the last does not appear to involve significant State funds other than the railroad.  The Knik Arm Bridge was initially sold as a project the private sector would compete to own cost free to the state.  It became a project funded solely by the state and Federal DOT has virtually laughed at the traffic projections based on the public bridge between Juneau and Douglas which is the sole link for them.  Yet the Knik project lives  on, destroying the Government Hill neighborhood, paying salaries, and as far as I know has no plan to link any bridge traffic to Anchorage roads.  I have heard the line "We have too much invested at this point to stop now" repeatedly since the pre-pipeline years.  Contractors have always driven the development priorities and only joined forces with oil.  They continue to influence those whose primary purpose is to be reelected.

Comment: With more than 10,000 a day turning 65 since 2012... vision and hearing loss disabilities seemed not to be a concern for those who aid conversation becoming communion. Large print, headphones, online access are new tools. If I were having lunch with Ely, I'd share how God is getting mileage out of my decline. I am online preparing for Mass using audio websites - with headphones... and websites that let me pop up the print size for the readings. Such gathering, turns the soil of my heart for the Sabbath. Sometimes, my online 'prep' is "it" for the Sabbath as my body isn't road worthy for attending Mass. It happens. And sometimes, my online 'prep'  and time in contemplation so deepens my communion in the Liturgy of the Word and Eucharist that the weave is greater than the sum of the parts. Sure! I globalized my issues and grumbled about 'stuff'. It is St. Paul's caution about that belt around the waist, and being led where I do not want to go. Brokenness is a loving teacher.

Comment: "ALL past Presidents have released their tax returns?"

Not according to this independent source.   

"Franklin Roosevelt did not release tax returns during his presidency, but many returns were later made available by his presidential library."

"Gerald Ford did not release his returns, but he did release summary data about his federal taxes for the years between 1966 and 1975"

Jimmy Carter did not release a return for 1980 nor did Ronald Reagan release one for 1988 

"Like all other citizens, U.S. presidents enjoy this protection of their privacy. Since the early 1970s, however, most presidents have chosen to release their returns publicly. In the hope of making this information more widely available, the Tax History Project at Tax Analysts has compiled an archive of presidential tax returns."

http://www.taxhistory.org/www/website.nsf/Web/PresidentialTaxReturns?OpenDocument

Comment: Key point - you're 45 years in practice.  So you're very much a part of an older generation of doctors.    My Dad was even older and worked similar hours (delivered babies too).   

One of the hidden and non-discussed issues is the choice of medicine as a life-style choice.   In the past (even older than your practice) - medicine was a calling.   It still is for many (hopefully the majority) but the reality is, a growing portion of our medical graduates chose medicine for the wrong reasons.    EG:  In a major urban center - try to find a young, female GP.    I was shocked at the number who required membership fees at a clinic where 6 partners worked the equivalent of 3 full time doctors.    These are the type of doctors complaining the loudest.      One of the hidden problems is the number of NEW graduates who end up working a part-time career as a choice because our system allows and rewards that.     That is a very poor use of a resource (and medical graduates are a resource.

Comment: The maximum cap when one should be able to collect a survivor benefit is nonsense. In any private pension, the survivor is paid regardless of any 'cap'.  The CPP does not have a funding problem. If someone contributes for 40 years (or whatever number) their 'survivors' should be entitled to collect.

As for why the public employees are treated differently, there is no good rationale other than labour peace. There is already a two tier retirement system in Canada, with public tax dollars funding 50% (or more) of retirement for public sector employees.

Offering them more advantages than Joe Public is simply wrong. They should not get full benefit after 35 years to the CPP portion of their pension, while others have to contribute 40 years for the same benefit.  The government's answer to the lack of pension (fairness) is to have employers and employees ramp up contributions to pad pensions. 

Pension reform should start with treating everyone equally.

Comment: That's a lot of guns, but your statistics aren't applied properly and are misleading. Actual gun ownership is confined to about 30% of citizens, down from over 50% in 1973, when percent of gun ownership peaked. If US population is 325 million and 30% own guns, then 97.5 million people own an average 3.38 guns apiece. And for two centuries, the Supreme Court basically left firearms possession up to local law.

Comment: The FBI has already reviewed tens of thousands of e-mails, and hasn't found any criminal activity in them.  There is no reason to believe that these e-mails, which for all we know are duplicates of ones they have already reviewed will show anything different.  Yet the Trump camp are trumpeting them as some sort of smoking gun, even though they have no idea what they contain.  The reason that Comey's action was illegal is that it allows Trump to smear Clinton with completely unfounded speculation and innuendo days before the election when she isn't able to access the e-mails to defend herself.  It may or may not have been Comey's intention to provide the Trump camp with this blunt but hollow weapon to pummel Clinton with, but it took only milliseconds for the Trump campaign to take it up and wield it, as insubstantial as it is.  This is the whole reason that the Justice department prohibits this type of disclosure in the last weeks of an election.  Comey should have known better.

The judge remains a higher power when it comes to legality of government policy.

Comment: My favorite example of RTD incompetence is the former Sky Ride. Once upon a time I could park at the Highlands Ranch lot off University and take a bus to the airport. The parking was free and the bus was under $20 roundtrip. It was reliable and took an hour. The parking lot was always full. Now it is empty. Then the RTD shut the bus down in preparation for forcing us all onto the "A" train. To use the "A" train I need to get myself three miles to a light rail station. There is a bus a few blocks away I can catch if I lug my bags over there. Hopefully not in the rain or snow. Then I take the light rail downtown, where I get to drag my bags half a mile to the "A" train. Which may or may not be running, depending on what breaks down that day. To be sure I get to the airport on time I need to leave my house at least four hours before flight time. Thanks, but no thanks. Bring back the SkyRide buses!

Comment: Glad you support the Lower Elwha's more traditional endeavors.   And I agree, gambling can be just as terrible an addiction as alcohol or drugs.

Conference centers don't attract tourists, they attract organizations.  If people are here for a professional event  --  training, corporate retreat, convention  --  they just need a place that can support what the event's organizers want to schedule.  Pretty things to look at outside the windows and good stuff to eat outside the doors seal the deal.  

Lots of PA folks spend the night or weekend in Victoria to attend cultural events  --  our new Performing Arts venue could create a reverse flow, especially with an elegant hotel that's walking distance from the cultural event. 

As to Esprit  --  they have to do some fancy finagling to support the events of their convention, but we're a pleasant enough destination that they come here anyway.  But how many other organizations would be willing to walk to the Elks for their dinner dance?

Comment: Regarding the abolition of the estate tax: During his campaign Trump stated that along with dropping the estate tax, he would also get rid of step up valuation at the time of death. Under current law, if your parent dies and leaves you the long time family home  and you sell it, your basis in the home is the value of it on the day they died, rather than what they bought it for.  This means that you will not show a gain from the sale and will have no taxable income from it. If Trump sticks to his plan to get rid of the ability to step up the basis, then when you sell the home that your parents bought a couple decades ago, you will likely show a significant taxable gain. Of course, Trump has also talked about getting rid of the capital gains tax at every income level, so in that case no one pays anything... This is something to watch as they reshape the tax code, as for many the only real asset they have is their home and it could be a downward shift in taxes.

Comment: I agree that the alternatives on offer are generally uninspiring, but that too was the case when Trudeau's Libs deposed Harper's tired regime. I would rather have Bernier leading the Cons and I see nothing compelling in any of the NDP's leadership aspirants. But governments tend to defeat themselves in this country. Trudeau's only accomplishments to date, like sort of getting along with Trump and a relatively robust but still fragile economy, have been achieved by default. But big minefields exist for the Libs on immigration, NAFTA and aboriginal affairs. On the latter issue, I suspect most Canadians have little interest in the models of aboriginal sovereignty proposed by many First Nations advocates. It will be almost impossible for Trudeau to achieve his vaunted new relationship with First Nations and keep the remaining 96% of Canadians mollified. And his broader predilection for identity pandering increasingly irritates many Canadians. The risks ahead are all Trudeau's to face.

Comment: I lived in East Africa for two years in the mid-90s and I took meflaquine the entire time with no side effects. Meflaquine was the only effective way to prevent cerebral malaria, which was a problem in the area where I lived. I knew that meflaquine had potential mental side effects because it was written right on the bottle that it could cause vivid dreams or psychosis.

Drug side effects are rare. They can explain a case or two but not an entire troop, which is what Canadian soldiers are claiming. This poor fellow who took his life had just been in Somalia and Rwanda during their most horrible phases. I was haunted for years by pictures of a US soldier being dragged behind a car in the streets of Somalia. The things this young man witnessed are more likely to have deranged him than his anti-malarial pill.

Malaria kills over a million people a year. Once in your system, it can plague you for decades. The people most in danger are ones who haven't had it before. Meflaquine is good.

Comment: The oil companies told us that if SB21 was passed it would create more jobs and increased state revenue. They didn't offer any qualifiers like the specific per barrel price of oil...they flat out said SB21 would increase revenue to the state and create more jobs in the industry.   Now...less than three years after the passage SB21, oil industry jobs are down over 16% and state revenue from oil has most assuredly not increased...quite the contrary. 

Its time to end this corporate welfare and repeal SB21. Too many Alaskans supported SB21 back in '14 but even they have to admit now that they got conned. Nothing the industry promised has come to fruition. One of the first orders of business in the new legislature should be a repeal of SB21.

Comment: Fear mongering by climate alarmists will not change things. Everyone know that Canada's contribution to worldwide CO2 is insignificant (less than 2%). Cutting our fossil fuel use or production in half wouldn't make a significant difference to worldwide CO2 emissions, but would implode the Canadian economy and cause huge job losses. Ranting by the enviros and academics won't change this.

You may put climate change at the top of your list of concerns, but most people really don't. And no government will sacrifice jobs and the economy in order to meet some worldwide temperature limit - just look at the US. Make it too painful for citizens and that government is gone (right Wynne?). 

Canada will show that it is doing something through a moderate carbon tax, so that we're not seen as a pariah (like the US) - but that's about it. The shift away from fossil fuels will take decades, not days.

Comment: My intent was not to advocate the 'post-truth' approach, but to illustrate that people have different realities.  My facts, from recent presentations/conversations with NOAA and other marine scientists indicate that the Southern Resident Killer Whales are in trouble. The problem is that they are undergoing a  of "death of a thousand cuts" experience. They are seeing reduced feeding success due to declining Chinook salmon stocks, are having problems hunting, communicating or resting due to increasing levels of noise in the marine environment, experiencing high morbidity among calves, have high levels of contaminants (e.g., PCBs) and many females that are at breeding age are not calving. A major oil spill event, that impacted the food web in our local waters for 10 years, could conceivably take them below a population threshold that could recover.

Currently the population is at 80+/- up from 67 whales in 1971. The numbers have biologists worried that the population will not survive.

Comment: "Those crucifixes are still direct endorsements of a specific religion by public bodies. That's why they were originally there."

Why something was originally there doesn't necessarily reflect why is it still there. Few women who get married wearing white wedding dresses today do so as an affirmation of their virginity, for example.

Today they serve as a reminder of a cultural heritage, i.e. "Je me souviens", the province's motto. Just as the fleur-de-lys on the flag and on the walls of the National Assembly isn't an expression of allegiance to the King of France, as it originally was, just to the language and culture inherited from that time.

They are not an expression of an active, personal faith, the way choosing to wear particularly extreme religious clothing is.

Comment: A lot of misinformation here. Digital over-the-air TV reception around Denver is excellent with indoor HDTV antennas, and I'm down south in the Greenwood Village area, facing east away from Lookout Mtn. Never any problems with weather, interference, etc. I get a lot of other channels that I like, not everyone would, but for free it's great. Comment: This is what happens when politicians tamper with what should be an open and free marketplace. The ACA and Obama promised coverage for millions more people while reducing price. They then proceeded to require all plans to include coverage for more conditions. They said all of this would still work because of increased efficiency (something our government is so well known for) and greater bargaining power. Clearly, the doctors were going to be on the losing end of this bargain as insurance companies were required to cover more people for more things for less money, and we all know how willing insurance companies are to operate at a loss. Comment: This report prompts  these comments:

1. There are credible assessments that more than 25% of BC's GDP is currently generated by the residential building boom which, in turn, depends upon the stimulus of the urban residential property bubble.  This bubble doesn't extend into the northern communities to any significant extent and, in any case, is arguably not sustainable.  It follows that the north does not participate in the reported economic growth of BC.

2. The north is languishing and this highlights for residents there the hollowness of the BC Liberal promise of LNG development induced prosperity.

3. The political question will be therefore whether northerners turn to the NDP because of BC Liberal failures or, conversely, they turn to the Liberals because the NDP is viewed as putting job growth at risk because of their emphasis on environment protection.

Polling currently suggests that the Liberals are the preferred if reluctant choice of northerners but this could change.

Comment: As someone who had both the measles and chicken pox as a kid and who has had both kids vaccinated, I think much of this discussion is way over the top.  As the article notes, there are only three provinces that make vaccinations mandatory in Canada. As far as I can tell there is no evidence that those provinces without mandatory vaccination have an more outbreaks than those provinces that don't.  In addition, there have been not widespread outbreaks that have caused serious harm in Canada in the last couple of decades.  Most of the so called outbreaks end up with less than 50 people contacting measles or chicken pox and other than missing a week of school, very little other consequences. Comment: Thanks for your reply, and I agree with much of what you say. My main points are that we should not be privatizing a public resource, much less giving it away, and that it not should become property that can be converted into capital.

With any limited resource, we need a fair way to distribute it, and permits are certainly a legitimate tool. I have a subsistence halibut permit - a permit type which is actually overly-generous and prone to abuse, I fear - but I can't pass it on, sell it, or even give it away. It doesn't cost anything and expires every two years. Fine.

Why don't we give perpetual, salable guiding rights to big game guides in wildlife refuges? Or perpetual, salable national forest cutting rights to timber companies? Or perpetual, salable vending rights to companies in national parks?  Absurd, right?

But when it comes to commercial fish, we've been sold the bill of goods that we have to give them away in order to manage them. Even more absurd. And, to me, criminal.

We DO have to wean ourselves from the addiction to ever inflating property values: enforcement of no commercial lodging activities in residential areas.  Period.  
Renting a spare room to a student is one thing. 3 AirBnB customers a month is another. Removing whole properties from long term rentals for lucrative vacation rentals is not aloha aina or pono in any way.
If residential units on Oahu were owned by people who lived in them, or had "long" term ( 30+ days) rentals we would not have a housing crisis. HOW do we incentivise the outcome we want (real neighborhoods for real residents)  NOT legislating a fix against greed (market forces)?

Comment: "I pledge allegiance to the Flag of the United States of America and to the Republic for which it stands, one nation, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all."
    -Francis Bellamy 1923

This is a pledge that reflects respect and allegiance to an entity meant to serve and protect the rights of all the human species in totality.  

We are gaining arduous headway, it may not look it sometimes, but we are successfully climbing out of the dark and relinquishing the grip of fear that has plagued our kind for far too long.  The realization that we alone have the responsibility for our own actions, that we sacrifice too much in delegating our choices of morality and truth to tradition blindly, and that we do not own a privileged point of existence - are well worth the pain the journey has cost us.

We have pressing problems the government needs to address, religion is an unnecessary distraction to that end.

 While I strongly believe that race is a fiction with no basis in reality, racism was/is unfortunately very much a reality.

Comment: Interesting. I can believe SA's "grassroots" corruption is fairly modest. With isolated exceptions like the taxi industry, small business owners aren't spending too much time buttering up local Big Men, from what I can tell -- at least in the urban economy. It doesn't take much imagination to see how THAT sort of corruption would make business difficult, and life unpleasant, in a way an Eskom prepayment simply doesn't. 

Perhaps our high-level crony-capitalist corruption is pretty normal too -- just less sophisticated than in, say, the USA. Our government has never been free from corrupt business influence. So perhaps the noise is partly just the sound of the changing corporate guard. Glencore out, Tegeta in. 

But we still must deal with the underlying problem: our government is way too big. 

Break up Eskom, sell SAA, decentralise SASSA, consolidate ministries, freeze hiring.

We can't stop people behaving badly, but we can limit the damage they can do.

Comment: That's some pretty revisionist history you've got going on there.  The fact that the Russian Empire "took" territory from the Ottoman Empire (not the Osman Empire) doesn't give them the right to keep it forever.  

The reason Crimean Tatars preferred to stay with Ukraine is that, after 25 years of Ukrainian independence, they were making slow but steady progress - the descendants of many of the Tatars that Stalin deported to other parts of Russia were returning to Crimea.  They were not "capturing the land as they wished," the Ukrainian government recognized that Stalin had wronged these people and were doing something - probably not enough, but at least something - to try to make up for that historical wrong.

Comment: CRS 18-3-203. Assault in the second degree
(1) A person commits the crime of assault in the second degree if:
...(d) He recklessly causes serious bodily injury to another person by means of a deadly weapon; or


Notes:
Under subsection (1)(d), any object, including a foot, may be a deadly weapon when used to start an unbroken, foreseeable chain of events that results in serious bodily injury. The object does not have to be the direct cause of the injury. Where defendant kicked the victim in the back, causing her to fall down a flight of stairs, it was irrelevant that her injuries were caused by the stairs rather than the defendant's foot. The defendant's foot qualified as a deadly weapon because he used it to set in motion a sequence of events causing a serious bodily injury. People v. Saleh, 45 P.3d 1272 (Colo. 2002).

Comment: No one who goes for a hike in the mountains ever expects to get lost, get caught in an unexpected blizzard, get struck by lightning, sprain an ankle, break a leg, or fall and break an arm. No one expects to have a heart attack or a stroke, either.
-
There are certain things all hikers can and do prepare for. They will take a bottle of water, snacks, and maybe a light rain jacket. But no one planning a day hike on a marked trail that they expect to have other hiker's on it will "prepare" for an overnight excursion.....must less 3 or 4 days. "It's just a day hike. To the top of this 14-er and back. Easy. Sort of. Be back in time to make dinner."
-
Yes, it's easy to say "He should have had this and that....along with that and this." But he didn't. Because, just like 90+% of the hikers out there, he took what he knew he needed for a simple hike and nothing more.
-
Almost all of us have done that, and almost all of us will continue to do that....because our day hike will be a day hike.

Comment: Forrest Dunbar is a single example, and not a great one necessarily because there's aspects of him that also appeal strongly to Republican voters, like his military service and hand in crafting the AK Code of Military Justice. Don Young I feel is an example that makes my point: he's repeatedly embarrassed the state on a national level, and yet keeps winning reelection by strong margins over people like Dunbar.

I agree, you could swing the needle in Alaska easier than another state because of population, but considering Alaska has gone red in every election since 1960 (with the exception of the massive blue sweep that was 1964), its hard to argue that a swing is likely. Yes the GOP is currently a trashcan fire, but the same was true in 04, 08, 12 and we still went decisively red. Looking at the number of Trump stickers I see on cars, I'm not confident that our electorate is actually getting smarter. Certainly it's possible Trump will cause a left-shift, but I'm not holding my breath.

Comment: Joanna I would suggest you volunteer as a Poll Worker.  You would then see how far off base your comments really are.  First and foremost there is an accounting at the poll site level.  The ballots are not only seen, but are counted and reconciled down to the ballot.  Including mis marked, destroyed or other wise compromised and questioned ballots.  There is a multiple paper trail including a printout that can be obtained by any poll watcher, the poll workers are required to verify and sign for the results.  Seals are checked and verified.  The ballots and equipment, at least in Anchorage, are hand carried by two workers to be turned in for counting.  While it makes for a very long day for the poll workers the accuracy and opportunity to ensure a fair and accurate election is more than worth it.  There may be even time for you to try it although vote by mail is gaining traction as we speak.

Comment: "Lies, damned lies, and statistics" is a phrase describing the persuasive power of numbers, particularly the use of statistics to bolster weak arguments. I read the research mentioned and I would cite the following:
-The sample size in this study allows the authors to come to the conclusion they want to come to in the first place
-Oregon Live has an article on the worst Oregon wildfires, http://www.oregonlive.com/wildfires/index.ssf/2017/09/the_worst_wildfires_in_oregon.html
-Of these, half are brush fires
-The others are forest fires. All were in old growth or reburns of previous fires that did not get salvaged
-The Elliot Forest, became state ownership after the original old growth was burnt around 1880.
-The B&B Complex, Whitewater Fire, Eagle Creek, Strawberry Wilderness, all unmanaged lands

Comment: A lyrical and engaging piece. The beauty of the writer's language - it's almost a prose poem in parts - attests his love of words and the delicacy of the question: should those who love words ever destroy books? Funnily enough, I thought about publishers pulping their own remainders before I reached the mention of it. Does it help if words are recycled into words (new books) rather than another form of art? Or to think of books simply as a means of communication rather than the end? (I'm not imagining we are talking here of destroying knowledge by destroying books; that's something completely different.)  I'd rather focus on the words and the alchemy of reading that lifts them off their mechanical reproduction on the page to work their magic on the heart and mind. But to defile any book is symbolic of a negative reaction and that, I think, is why it feels uncomfortable.

And if any of these third parties get enough votes, they become eligible to participate in future debates and could become a force in future elections.  We need more than two items on the menu.

Comment: Understand your wish to seek restitution from "perpetrators."
Here are some reasons why the government has taken the  route:

1. The claimants remain anonymous, no fear of threats or recrimination. They've suffered enough.

2. They will not have to relive their debilitating experiences  in court. Nor will they be challenged and denigrated in the "adversarial" atmosphere.

3. The chance of "guilty" verdicts in sexual cases is minimal, as thousands of victims of sexual crimes who take legal action will attest. 

4. There is no delay--restitution is practically immediate, after these women have waited years, already.  They need not wait much longer.

5. Tax-payers would pay huge court costs. Perhaps higher costs than this settlement. 

6. Under the terms of this restitution, there is no "blanket" payment. There are six levels of payment based on circumstances and impact on the victim's life and career.

Comment: This is an excellent article, and of course there's a lot more to come as it's early days for analysis and fact-finding on this file.

If not, why not? Would a private lender not have at least consulted competent legal advice to ensure the company's assets stay in Canada? Particularly after the Canadian government gave so much cash to GM to keep it afloat and then to see the production in Canada move elsewhere.

To become a major player in the commercial aircraft business, massive (government) subsidies, such as those involved in creating Airbus, would be needed. Surely this was a known known when Bombardier decided to compete against the Big Two. What must its management have been thinking?

Comment: When Oahu first voted for rail, we were sold a product that was far superior to what will eventually be built, at a much lower price than we're seeing now.  Back in November 2008, we approved a project that was projected to run all the way to Ala Moana at an estimated price (at that time) of $4.28 billion.  The citizens vote favored rail by 51% to 46%, a pretty small margin.

Now the product we're being forced to buy is significantly inferior to what we agreed to purchase, and it's being sold to us a much higher price.  If any other entity tried to do this to me, I could refuse to pay or take it to court to adjudicate.  But in this instance, I am completely powerless to do anything because the government has the power to take my money and mismanage it as they see fit.  

Mufi, Caldwell, Grabauskas, everyone in charge in managing this project should be ashamed of themselves for doing such a disservice to Oahu.  We entrusted you to do the right thing, but you failed spectacularly.

Comment: The driving goal behind automation was to reduce the number of workers needed to pick up refuse. Worker safety was a distant second reason. Because refuse service is mandatory within the old city limits of Anchorage.  SWS can force customers to use any cans they want.  Government Hill is under SWS / Muni rules , while the other 80 percent of Anchorage can take or leave refuse service any time they want .  Tell those 80 percent they have to use bear resistant carts and they'll simply quit service .  The point being that with so few willing to use bear resistant carts----if for no other reason than having to lock and unlock them every time they want to place refuse inside or being charged for forgetting to unlock them on collection day----bear resistant cans will have next to no impact on bears eating refuse.   I'm not knocking you for trying , but just saying getting Anchorage as a community to use them won't ever happen. Just as recycling is failing as well , but for other reasons  .

Comment: I believe you are exactly right:  AI will automate millions of jobs out of existence, beginning with driving-related ones over the next 5 - 10 years.  Office and knowledge workers will not be immune.  At first, it will be a gradual shift, where AI will take on an "assist" role: head-office will not lay off Tim in Finance to be replaced by a robot right away, but they won't hire that extra headcount or contract worker.  But with increasing workplace penetration, machine learning and algorithms will start improving exponentially, and eventually supplant more and more people.  I could see very significant impacts on employment and society within the next 15-20 years.  Is it reasonable to think that new jobs and professions will sprout to replace the old ones?  Maybe, but many (most) will remain under or unemployed. What will people do without meaningful work?  How will they pay for food and rent?  Brace for huge social unrest and accelerated wealth concentration at the top of the pyramid.

Comment: "Fluctuations in economic time series are caused by seasonal, cyclical and irregular movements. A seasonally adjusted series is one from which seasonal movements have been eliminated. Seasonal movements are defined as those which are caused by regular annual events such as climate, holidays, vacation periods and cycles related to crops, production and retail sales associated with Christmas and Easter. It should be noted that the seasonally adjusted series contain irregular as well as longer-term cyclical fluctuations. The seasonal adjustment program is a complicated computer program which differentiates between these seasonal, cyclical and irregular movements in a series over a number of years and, on the basis of past movements, estimates appropriate seasonal factors for current data." Statistics Canada

Comment: Courts are very reluctant to do over elections. Did you read the Steve Haycox op-ed  piece about the Hickel Hammond primary fight of 1978?  Hammond won by 98 votes. A number of significant irregularities came to light. 

" In Anchorage a temporary election worker responsible for transporting about 2,000 challenged ballots from a computer center to the district election office kept them in his car trunk overnight. In the Native villages of Kwethluk and Kotlik, 141 ballots were discarded after being counted, rather than being mailed to the Division of Elections, as the law required.  Then, 15 ballots in the Juneau election office were found to have been misplaced during the recount.  Finally, 247 challenged ballots were found to have been placed in an unlocked file cabinet in the Anchorage office. Irregularities indeed!"

The Alaska Supreme Court allowed the election to stand, regardless.

http://www.adn.com/opinions/2016/09/22/the-ticket-reminds-us-of-some-wild-alaska-election-history/

And it is just as bad in Alaska,  which just cut 115,000 chinook from its summer troll quota,  and has only produced about 19,000 winter troll fish since last October to date.  

Treaty tribes that troll in WA got a 40,000 chinook quota.  The other 50% in the Boldt Decision got 7400 chinook for CA border to Queets River line,  7400 for Queets to Ledbetter,  and 7400 from Ledbetter to Cape Falcon, OR.  There is a rec fish quota as well.  Unlimited from Falcon to Humbug Mtn.  Coos Bay is open to sports,  as are Bandon and Windy Bay.

Comment: Ms Pturley:  You are ever so right......if it walks like a power-grab; quacks like a power-grab and smells like a power-grab, there's a pretty good chance it's a power-grab.  The "county concern" metric, as you say, is subjective....I would suggest intentionally so.  It gives the Board of Commissioners carte blanche authority to veto any initiative they choose.  It's a egregious constitutional violation which, essentially, deprives citizens of the initiative right.  The initiative process was designed and placed in the US and Oregon Constitutions specifically to provide citizens a direct "recourse for grievances" vis a vis an over-reaching and controlling legislative body.  The Board's assumption of a preemptive veto power to keep initiatives off the ballot negates that constitutionally protected citizens' power.  IMO, a Board truly dedicated to democracy would not even want such power, let alone try to grant it to themselves.  regards, Gary

Comment: These tax credits are not about Alaskan jobs.  There is an oil rig tied up at the Homer dock.  The state is footing 65% of the bill.  100% of the crew on that rig are from Louisiana and nearby gulf states.  In Anchor Point area a large seismic job is going on.  Almost 100 people are employed.  5 employees might actually be eligible for a PFD.  The rest are from out of state. Again the state is paying 65%.  If the oil rig hits oil, the state will get back 12.5% royalty and zero production tax after paying full cost to lift and transport.   Pay 65% up front, get back 12.5% on the back end.  If the rig hits gas, the state will get 17 cents per mbu.  Enstar just signed a five year contract to pay $7.52 per mbu.  On the North Slope, the state taxes on the net profit and rebates those taxes as a percentage of the gross price.  This virtually ensures that the remaining 3.5 billion barrels of easy lift oil will be sold for next to nothing in production taxes.  "Asinine"!

Comment: It's not about today's reading on the inflation rate.  Interest rates are set on the basis of where inflation is expected to be in 18-24 months. Comment: The banks' argument about stability is ridiculous.  The implication is that somehow the broker channel lenders are unstable and/or there is some risk in working with them.  This makes no sense. 

Looking at the bigger picture might have some value, but it will come with a sales pitch for the bank's other products.   Many of these products (eg mortgage insurance, credit insurance, mutual funds) are a terrible waste of money that would never be recommended by an unbiased advisor.

Most people end up at banks because it seems easy, because of their massive spend on branding, or because they don't know there are options.  It's too bad that more people don't learn a bit about the real differences between banks and brokers.   Banks deserve to get a harder time about the lousy deals they offer their mortgage customers.

Comment: Went to pay my bill at the hospital  today and the lady who took my cash had a certificate on her wall that said she had achieved her training to be a certified health care counselor to patients and assisting them with applying for the Affordable Care Act. I asked her how that is going. The clerk said that before the ACA was enacted the hospital was forced to take low payments from a lot of insurance programs and had to "eat" the costs or pass it on to their customer base as a whole. The patients never knew, they would get a co-pay for 50 bucks never aware of the fact that the should have had a co-pay 10 times more than that. The clerk said that the money from the ACA helped them to collect what the procedures and treatments provided needed to receive in order not to continue to take less all of the time. Many Alaskans have gone to get much needed care now instead of waiting long times, sometimes years leading to access to preventative care and early treatment improving their health.

Comment: I worked for a little while for Golden Wheels, back in 1975. I drove an 18-wheeler that hauled the big merry-go-around, operated several of the rides, and did some carpenter work. Some of the older rides were a patch-work of repairs, often broken parts had not been replaced, just welded:
Not enough rides back then to spread/reduce mechanical wear and tear, which increased upkeep costs, which reduced how much they could pay workers, which attracted lower quality employees, which led to rides and equipment being handled poorly, which increased wear and tear.
An 18-wheeler hauling the "Hammer" and "Octopussy" rides, and the glass truck (dime-toss glass) were destroyed in the hair-pin corner at Mile 42 on the old Haines highway, by young pot-head drivers.
We were scheduled to set up in Haines that summer, but the city fathers upped the required "fees" so high, that the owners decided to continue on to S.E. Alaska ahead of schedule.
Today I looked at all their rides. Much better!

Comment: I don't think that's quite right.  We get downstream benefits from the power produced in the US, so they pay us a royalty for the power they create from their generation.  Teck uses power from the Waneta dam in the smelter operations in Trail, and did sell the excess to the US.  There was a partnership when Waneta was upgraded with Columbia Power Corp.  BC Hydro just recently bought Teck's portion (but Teck will still use the power) I think power is sold to the US because the transmission lines service the US, not Canada.
The Treaty is going to be re-negotiated, and the US wants to stop paying us royalties from their power production.
There's a bunch of stuff online about it, which makes for confusing reading.

Comment: When I divide the pop. growth in the Lower Mainland by housing completions, I get a number that is substantially lower than the average household size (~2.1 against ~2.6). Perhaps it's worth checking this for the GTA as well? For the Lower Mainland, this data suggests that ample supply is being made. The need then is to examine whether the supply being built meets shelter demand (would require legislation/ incentives to drive building of units with more bedrooms), as well as to assess whether this "demand" is being driven by demand for something other than demand for shelter (which has a lot less to do with population growth than it does with speculation [either foreign or domestic]).

It's worth noting that the population growth rate in the Lower Mainland was larger 10-20 years ago, when prices were relatively flat. And that rents here, even with recent increases, are less than the carrying costs for owning (very true for detached houses). This does not suggest demand for shelter.

Comment: Good read, but I'm nonetheless of the opinion that 28 pounds in only six months (that would be 56 in a year!) is way, way, way too fast, and you're never going to be able to maintain it. You managed to endure your regimen for six months, and you probably figure that now you're at a decent weight you'll be able to slack off a little and just maintain. Or maybe you're going to try to keep up the relatively boring nutritional plan, three days/wk of weights and three days/wk of running. Either way, I wish you luck. Please, please, please -- in the upcoming three years, write at least a yearly follow-up article. Anyone with sufficient will-power can hang in for six months -- that's not the test. It's what happens after that initial period of will power has been frittered away by a million day-to-day factors that tells the story. Personally, I find that any plan that loses more than 12 pounds per year is ultimately unsustainable and is setting you up for failure further down the road.

Comment: I found this story very interesting because I crossed the border from Canada to the U.S. at Norton, Vermont early in July.  It is on a back-country road.  Definitely remote. I did not see any homes or other buildings around the check point and wondered where the border control agents lived.  Nortonâs population was 169 in 2010.  The nearest âlargeâ town is Island Pond, 16 miles south.  Its population was 821 in 2010, but it does have a few shops that serves people living in the surrounding wilderness.  It is a beautiful area, hilly and wooded with many streams and lakes.   Great place for hunting and fishing.  Summers are short and cool summers; winters are long, cold and miserable.   My wife and I wondered why anyone would want to work there except perhaps hard-core locals.  Customs and Border Protection apparently is wondering the same thing.

Comment: I'll address this one point of yours:

"The sky is falling?"

Yes, it is falling (metaphorically speaking of course).   It's falling very slowly though and it may not crush us to death but we will have to adjust - as a species of course.

I'm not talking about in our lifetimes and I'm not just talking about climate change.   I'm talking about other damage to the planet.   Coral reefs are suffering and there is over-fishing and there is significant plastic and other toxic pollution in the ocean and I really like seafood.

And coral reefs support 25% of ocean life.

But even if you're a vegan or a strictly beef-eater things might not be so great in the future either.   Grazing land is being destroyed and there are droughts and diseases.   

I do have hope though.  Maybe we can hold up the sky somehow with advancements or maybe we can adapt.   I won't be alive to see it and our children won't either.  Time moves slowly on a geological scale, grasshopper

Comment: Outsider:  Damn it, man, I really enjoy arguing with you, and on this one it's really hard.  With population growth, urbanization and industrialization in, as you point out, especially China and India, our "carbon footprint" just keeps growing.  The best we can do is to try to "slow it down."  Unless there's a concerted and coordinated worldwide commitment to address all the factors (including population growth), we're doomed to ever-increasing and ever-accelerating warming. 

Yes, we should do what we can to slow it.  But, at the same time, we'd best make significant strides toward needed long-term adjustments to live with it as best we can.  That includes such things as decreased "waste" of water, and reassessing what locations are habitable....especially, already extremely dry areas and very low elevation and vulnerable coastal regions.  It won't be pretty.   Regards, Gary

Comment: "Are you saying that because we can't predict the future we shouldn't act as stewards of the environment?"

No, there are differing levels of what "stewards of the environment" can mean.  I believe in reasonable environmental policies, but not policies based upon alarmist propaganda.  Saying things like "Climate change is the greatest threat humanity has ever faced" is pure propaganda and outright false.  I know (not think) that capitalism and economics will transform society in 200 years more than CO2 emissions will transform the environment in 200 years.  We can be reasonably certain of that based upon history and science alone, barring some cataclysmic event such as a Yellowstone eruption or nuclear war or asteroid impact.

What is often ignored in the climate change debate are the costs of government policies, particularly opportunity costs, and only a vague declaration of the possible benefits (without evidence).  Anything we do to limit growth and progress might not be worth it.

Comment: "But if you have no real choice about "agreeing" - they are rules."

It's clear that everyone has a real choice in the matter. Either to attend the private school and agree to its principles, or not to attend. If I recall correctly the BC Court of Appeal affirmed that point. No one's forced to attend TWU, and there are many options available for those don't want to.

With respect to the 2001 SCC decision, it's not up to the SCC nor anyone else to decide what a student feels is a fair personal cost. Comment: A lot of things are left out of this article. When America was first founded, there was no welfare, no medical insurance, no food stamps. If you came to the country as an immigrant, it was up to you to survive. Land was plentiful but it was up to you to clear it and make a house from logs. It was a tough life, but people came for religious and civil freedom and a new start, to get away from religious persecution and the aristocratic levels of society that restricted them from higher occupations.

This is not the case at all today. Many people from poorer countries would love to come to the more developed nations, not necessarily for religious and civil freedom, but for money and prosperity. And since there are welfare and medical systems in place, the cost of an immigrant to the nation is much higher than in the days of the Revolution. Because of these costs, unlimited, borderless, immigration would ruin the economy of any developed nation today.

Comment: Fans have no desire for "brakes", nor should they, they are fans after all. Through all that, a few of us were defending TS, saying "it's too early for those labels" and very few were saying "pump the brakes" then.

Fans want the thrill of being 1st to cross the finish line, with every heart stopping moment and every breath taking spectacle that makes them cling to their seats and squeal for more along the way. That's football, that's entertainment and that's what fans love.

So damn the brakes, full speed ahead! GO BRONCOS!

Comment: Interesting question. I think, for Cape Town's MyCiti anyway, the large cost was for totally new infrastructure - stations, dedicated lanes and, of course, brand new (Brazilian) buses with their touch-'n-go card pay systems. MyCiti is based on cities like Curitiba, except those examples could not easily be applied to SA's apartheid-era spatially inefficient, decentralised urban planning, which added to MyCiti's cost (long distances). 
The selling point for these systems is they're 'rapid' - buses in dedicated lanes are not going to get stuck in traffic like other motorists, so people would want to use them, and it's cheaper than private car (fuel, wear & tear, long travelling times on congested roads).  Note other cities w/ functioning, efficient mass bus systems like London and Rome don't use dedicated lanes except here and there. So there's your billions, not overpriced tenders.
BTW Cape Town has increased street 2017 parking rates by almost 60% to about R17/hr, above private rates!

Comment: Mental disability is not treated any differently they only classify the animal differently.  It is called emotional support animal or ESA.  And even international airlines recognize and follow the federal rules regarding these animals for American travelers.  As long as you're flying
From America to your destination and back to America.  

The fact that our local airlines dropped the damn ball is absurd.  As long as you have a letter from a doctor (doesn't matter If your disability is mental or physical) then you have a legal right to your service or ESA animal.  This not only includes flying, transport but living arrangements as well.  Places that don't accept pets must accept a service animal because it is legally not considered a pet.  Don't like the laws? Lobby against them.  But the law is the law.

Comment: WTH did people think was going to reduce all the various forms of pollution, and its consequences?

For generations we have lived like spoiled brats on this planet--& we continue to do so.
We buy useless & wasteful & unnecessary things that even our parents',& certainly our grandparents' generations, would be horror-stricken by. How many vehicles? 'Entertainment centres'? See-doos? Leaf-blowers? Disposable diapers? Plastic bags?

How many tons of natural resources do those things consumer? Wood, precious metals, energy to obtain them, manufacture them, ship them, advertise them, sell them, dispose of them?

And we have given not one single damn, for our children or their children. The latest toy or outfit has been more important.

Suck it up buttercup--the bill is long past due.

Comment: It's raining outside.....must be those damn public employees causing it... The PERS unfunded mandate is a creation of public employERS taking the "short, easy way out" and not funding the "PERS-pick-up" as it was due. Comment: Feb 29th 1504 was a good day for Christopher Columbus too. For several months the famous explorer had been marooned on the island of Jamaica. He had been greeted warmly by the natives who helped him and his vast ship and crew survive in the foreign land by providing food and guides etc. However his arrogance and disrespect for the people had caused them to stop this gesture of goodwill. Cause, you know, he was being a dick.

Outraged by this, Columbus consulted his shipboard almanac to ask if there was anything he could use to trick the natives. As it happens, there was a lunar eclipse coming up. On the 29th feb, the day of the eclipse, he gathered the natives and told them that god was angry for their disrespect and would take away the sun. Disappearing inside his ship during the eclipse, he waited as the good people begged for their women and children. He agreed to 'bring the sun back', and essentially enslaved the people until he was rescued.

WHAT A DICK.

Comment: The oceans have a remarkably stable PH of 8.2-8.3.  That's alkaline, not acidic.

What idiot is recommending lower levels of CO2?  We're coming off dangerously low levels during the Maunder Minimum.  Life ceases to exist at levels below 150 ppm, and thrives at levels well above 1200 ppm.  The Earth has experiences levels of around 10,000 ppm during about half a dozen cycles as life was developing.  "Normal" is between 1200 and 2000 ppm.

Comment: "Why aren't several seasoned and formidable former senior Cabinet Ministers or Premiers contending?"  Your question answers itself.  Senior Harper cabinet ministers like Kenney and MacKay took a look at the federal landscape and decided it was futile.   As for premiers, most of them understand that premiers never do well at the federal level, because they're too associated with pushing the interests of a particular region.  The last premier to become a party leader was Bob Stanfield, 40 years ago.  I don't believe any former premier has run for any federal party's leadership since then, except for Bob Rae, who was arguably a special case because he had switched parties and had spent a fairly long period out of politics.

Comment: Regarding Bill Sherwonit's letter and John Shandelmeier's comment that "Ethics control the practice" with respect to killing caribou cows accompanied by calves, if true, that explains it.  No longer do ethics have much at all to do with hunting.  I am surprised that Mr. Shandelmeier hopes "this isn't something we (the Alaska Board of Game) need to regulate". To the contrary, the Alaska Board of Game, at the behest of its sport hunting constituency, has been deregulating ethics in hunting and trapping for decades, to the point where there is little left.  To depend on those hunters, who have supported and promoted this decline, to self-regulate on any issue, especially ethical ones, is nonsense.

Comment: I'm not sure what you mean by the NPV being a red herring. Comment: Air fryers are great if you use them right. "Fried" foods that are lightly misted with oil first will turn out crisper and more evenly cooked. Fish comes out great if you cook it on high heat for about 10 minutes per inch of thickness. Chicken wings are excellent, better than baked and not as oily as fried, so your hot wings can be a bit healthier. Honestly, there are better ways to cook a steak, but you also avoid all the oil splatter that often comes with frying on the stove.

Comment: After moving to the Waianae Coast almost six years ago, I was pleasantly surprised to see Honolulu was among the vanishing number of U.S. communities that still had a functioning daily newspaper, albeit a rather average one.
As the years have passed, so too has the functionality of the Star-Advertiser, which has whittled itself down to the hollowed-out journalistic shadow of so many of its U.S. cohorts.
On the mainland, I had previously canceled my subscription, when the community-newspaper there had downsized itself into irrelevancy.
Now, with subscription prices rising and editorial coverage shrinking, it's time again to question the continued relationship I keep with my community newspaper here on Oahu.
Without anything of interest to read, what is there left worth paying for?

Comment: "I have had someone grab my hand and I just then submit."  

Yes, me too.  And that's what I'm saying.  We shouldn't be in the position of "submitting," but it happens all the time.   I know there are perfectly sweet-hearted people who have no idea that their well-meant gesture might be an imposition --- or, who knows? the gesture could be completely welcomed --- but it seems the safer thing is not to extend a hand unless you have good reason to think it will be accepted.  Where I went to Mass this morning --- we chant the Agnus Dei, the Credo and the Gloria --- no one held hands.  If I'd missed that Mass and had to go to another parish later this evening, I'd have to expect someone reaching for me.  They'd have a reason to assume it was OK with me.  But thus illustrates a good point.  We used to be one; now we're splintered.  Whether to hold hands is a rather minor thing, but it exemplifies deeper divisions.  That's not good.

Comment: This is more common than you may think.  I was 1 of 4 Jewish kids in a large high school in eastern PA.  The amount of crap I took from teachers and/or administrators because I am not Christian was pretty damn frustrating.  That crap was everything from being sent to detention for not wanting to sing Christmas songs praising Jesus as a part of a required Christmas pageant, to being told pointedly that I would fail a class if I missed a day for the Jewish High Holidays.  Those holidays happen early enough in the school year that there is no way I wouldn't be able to make up the work, but since the teacher had scheduled a test for that day, with no way to make it up, I was out of luck as far as he was concerned.  Thankfully, my parents are both incredibly pushy and managed to make most of the problems go away without resorting to suing.

As for the Christmas songs, I would have been fine if they had been the secular Rudolph and Santa type songs, but not full on religious ones.

Comment: I'm not aware of right wing students trying to shut down left wing speakers. Certainly not in recent history. (*) possibly not students - hard to tell when they were wearing Balaclavas - but there are lots of other examples.

Comment: I appreciate this column and generally agree with the publisher's comments. One exception regards what seems to me as a weak comment regarding the tree services: "... during the reporting window were able to only reach the one profiled." The 20 or so tree services in the area were (and still are) very busy, and I doubt any of them have a marketing/PR staff to respond promptly to reporter inquiries.  Enlarging the reporting window might not have made much difference, but a reporter could have always gone to a job site or two for a quick comment or photo. And among other things it would be interesting to know how much money this is costing people (not that the tree services don't deserve the money), and what can be done other times of year to reduce the potential for damage in these storms. At least the contact information for the one service (and I have nothing against that family) is no longer at the end of the article.

Comment: What is "miniscule" to some of us (myself included), who largely feel that we aren't going to be negatively impacted by climate change in our lifetime, isn't quite as small a concern to those trying to make a living, raising a family, or dwelling in the areas of concern ( Asia, Middle East, Africa, S. America). The concerns/actions of their governments will cause impacts on our world political scene. 

When oil companies, the timber and wood products industry, fishing interests, the Department of Defense, state wild land fire agencies, and city and county governments in the SE of the United States are already taking this seriously, it doesn't matter whether you take this agree or not. Climate change denial is increasingly seen as a untenable and reactionary position by many non-Green entities, both private and public. Are they all blind too? 

Your thoughts about the option of nuclear power do mirror my own. I just don't think private industry is going to do it. They'd need help.

Comment: John McDowell--
My family has been in Alaska since 1899. If that's carpetbagging, we'll then I guess I'm guilty. 

We were here long before any oil money -- when we had the second highest income tax rate in the US. Back in 1960, (my first year in Alaska) we also had pretty expensive state government.
State spending was the 6th highest  per capita in the US. Schools were better than they are today and goverment services weren't fancy --but they were certainly adequate. Today we're not only #1 in per capita spending, we're first by such a wide margin, we're huge statistical outlier compared to other states.

Too long with too much money and we have forgotten how to live like mere mortals. 

Like I said before: Happy to pay an
income tax,  just as soon as we rein-in state government to a reasonable size.

Comment: There is a concept in economics called Kuznets environmental curve, which says that (environmentally harmful) wealth creation  can create the capacity for producing good environmental policy. As a recurring theme, it has largely become the foundation of most environmentally oriented arguments that point to maintaining the status quo.  The fat gets put into environmental policy - which often ends up having has as much a chance of being greenwashing as anything else.  Unless the results of Kuznets environmental curve can produce permanent and functional shifts it is a redundant argument that amounts to 1 step forward and 1 or 2 steps back.  The pipelines for Carbon tax/environmental policy trade-off  we are being sold is a good example.  How good is the plan for a "transition"?  How serious is the government about implementing it?

Comment: I follow John Heinzl's columns and model account with interest whenever it is available.  I am not criticizing and only offering suggestions as follows:  The investment industry is now being required to stop using percentages and start presenting real dollar values.  An example used on business news yesterday talked of a person with a 1M RRSP in mutual funds with a cost of 2.5%.  Doesn't sound like much until you convert it to a $25,000 cost.  For years I have always converted and know exactly how much money I am paying or getting.  If John converted all of his percentages to cash values, he would be following the new method and we might see a different picture.
In addition to John's holdings, I only have one bank, National and one telecom, BCE.  I have three pipelines and REITs.  I chose the ones that pay highest dividends because if you don't intend to sell, then capital value doesn't really matter.

Comment: Build the dam thing (tee hee).  Where are some leaders who have the vision to complete a useful megaproject??  It seems like in the modern era, all public projects are falling into the classic pattern of military procurement - the contractors know it has to be finished, the workers too, and so everybody involved takes their sweet time from day one. So you get these astounding numbers, where costs turn out to be double and triple the original estimates.   You need a leader or two with the guts to fire out the first few contractors who miss deadlines, or cry they need 2x more money.  Where is WAC Bennett when we need him?  CD Howe?  Louis St Laurent?  A Canadian FDR??    If we are pretty sure of the water situation and the power-generating potential of the dam, we ought to be able to get it built in a reasonable time, on or near the budget.
